pgTitle: List of Fame (1982 TV series) episodes

rows.text: An evaluation of the school has been imposed by members of the school board. This evaluation has observers sitting in on all classes throughout the day observing the students in their classroom and conducting interviews with each student to get an idea of their priorities in an unusual school like the School of the Arts. After spending time in the school, head inspector Mr. Melendez decides to use some of the budget for pre-existing programs to build a gymnasium as state regulations specify an hour of P.E. per day. Lydia sets out to prove that her dance class is strenuous enough to serve as a substitute for a conventional P.E. class by putting football jocks through one of her intense dance sessions. When the jocks fail to keep up in her class, she successfully proves her case. Leroy's troubled, estranged older brother Willard has just gotten out of jail and his first stop after emancipation is at the School of the Arts to ask his brother for shelter. Willard moves in with his brother where Leroy discovers a gun hidden in a drawer. Sensing trouble after seeing Willard drunk and learning that he’s hidden a gun in Leroy’s apartment, Ms. Sherwood and Coco try to appeal to Leroy’s common sense to no avail. Leroy asks his brother to get rid of the gun but instead ends up trying to dispose of it in a dumpster where he is arrested by an undercover cop. Awaiting news on the possible pressing of charges against him, Leroy uses the time to reflect and decides to send Willard away.

Mr. Martelli vents his frustrations on the fact that his talented son refuses to perform for anyone. The School of the Arts is holding its 7th annual benefit with Montgomery running the auditions as well as organizing the show. Coco tries to get Bruno to perform at the event with their band but he feels that the music isn’t ready. Mr. Shorofsky has revamped his usually private student proficiency tests and now asks that the tests be performed in front of the class. When it is Bruno’s turn to play his piece, he plays atrociously and asks to play for Mr. Shorofsky in private to which he contests. Mr. Shorofsky overtly addresses Bruno’s fear. Danny, conversely, wants to perform for the benefit but is not given the blessing by Montgomery and takes his frustration out on Doris who received a spot in the show. Montgomery informs Leroy that he’s in the show but Miss Sherwood imposes a restriction on Leroy’s performance privileges because his academic grades aren’t high enough. Leroy tries to sway Miss Sherwood’s decision by doing another assignment for extra credit but she sticks to her word. At the benefit a brown out traps Danny and Doris in an elevator which gives them time to gain an understanding for each other and inspires the kids to bring music to the halted show.

When dance major Kathleen is given an opportunity to audition for a spot in the Ran Tyler dancer troop, Miss Grant asks Bruno to compose an original piece for her to audition to. Upon collaborating, Bruno and Kathleen struggle to see eye to eye on the concept for the music. During their first rehearsal, Kathleen falls and injures herself. Upon examination at the hospital, the doctor diagnoses the injury as minor requiring only a minor procedure. Miss Grant has asked for a postponement on Kathleen's audition as she heals but through her stay at the hospital, the school's health and accident insurance company learns that Kathleen received prior diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. Miss Grant is left to decide whether or not to let her dance but learns in faculty meeting she learns that Kathleen will have to leave the school regardless, as the insurance company will not cover the school if Kathleen remains enrolled in the dance program. Meanwhile, Bruno and Kathleen fall for each other and after unknowingly receiving and listening to a tape of the meeting, Doris gives Bruno the shocking news. Miss Grant picks Leroy to fill in for Kathleen and when Kathleen tells Bruno that she plans to fight to remain enrolled, Leroy fakes an injury and the rest of the gang plan a surprise audition for the visiting members of the Tyler troop. Danny and Julie have been assigned a love scene by drama teacher Mr. Crandall. Danny begs Mr. Crandall for a different scene and Julie tries to get Miss Sherwood to convince Mr. Crandall to change his mind. The kids stage the scene methodically to get around Danny’s height issue.

Coco is instructing the dance class choreography mid-term but with her authoritative teaching methods she upsets her peers. Mr. Shorofsky has chosen Julie to play in the ensemble for Coco's project and Coco opposes. Seeking union from Miss Grant, Coco learns that she has no control over the musicians so she instead gives Julie a hard time during rehearsals. With everyone annoyed with Coco, all are baffled by what could possibly be rubbing Coco the wrong way with Julie. Doris has a hunch it is Coco’s interest in astrology and bets that Julie has the wrong sign. Miss Grant opts to get to the bottom of the problem. Coco tells Miss Sherwood that she has a problem with Julie's sign confirming Doris’ hunch. Bruno has promised to compose a lullaby for his soon arriving cousin on her birthday but with a mid-term pileup and his pregnant aunt Beatrice due soon, he's expecting things to get busy. Things get more complicated when Mr. Martelli causes a small fire in one of Bruno's synthesizers. Feeling guilty, Mr. Martelli buys Bruno a brand new expensive synthesizer and has to do extra work to pay off the debt he owes. Mr. Martelli's extended shifts 'cause him injury (dozing of and getting whiplash while driving). Bruno offers to get a part-time job to help his father out but his father forbids him. Despite his father's objection, Bruno secretly gets a job playing accordion for a polka band. Mr. Martelli is upset to learn that Bruno had been lying to him but Bruno surprises his father when Beatrice delivers early and he finishes the lullaby.

Mr. Crandall gives his students an assignment where they are to perform a scene or improv portraying a character that is as far removed from them as possible. With the idea to portray a prostitute, Doris dresses up one night standing on a street corner with other prostitutes where she and 16 year-old Tracy, a real prostitute, meet and are brought to a juvenile detention hall by a couple of cops. After her mother comes to pick her up, Doris convinces her mom to take Tracy in. When Tracy expresses an interest in enrolling in the school of the arts, Doris convinces the staff to allow her to audition despite auditions being held three months later; however, after a poor singing audition, she takes off. Doris convinces the run-away to call her parents before delivering an A+ performance for her drama class. Mr. Shorofsky has applied for a loan from the credit union to buy a classic car from some friends moving away in an attempt to invest in appreciating property. He asks Miss Sherwood to teach him to drive but is easily annoyed by her scrupulousness. When Mr. Shorofsky and Miss Sherwood go to pick up the car – with the steering wheel on the wrong side, they realize that driving is perhaps not for him.

Miss Grant, Miss Sherwood, and Mr. Crandall have all noticed that Danny's attitude and performance in his classes has dwindled. Miss Sherwood has observed this change and challenges Danny on the cause of his behavioural change, suggesting either drugs or lack of sleep. Danny has been working early mornings as the stage manager at a late night comedy club. He is thrilled to learn that his boss is giving him a spot with the departure of the club's star comedian who gives Danny caffeine pills as a "gift." Between balancing school and feeling like neither his parents nor his friends are supporting his work as a comedian, Danny turns to the drugs before heading out to perform. Miss Sherwood catches Danny on his first night putting his enrolment at the school of the arts in jeopardy. Danny's father discovers the drugs on Danny's nightstand but doesn't confront him until after he and the kids crash his talent event with a comedic/musical performance at the Knights of Saint Anthony Lodge; something Mr. Amatullo isn't too thrilled about. Montgomery brings Doris to a television commercial cattle call where she wins the part in a commercial for Hank Burgers but Doris detests the director and the burgers themselves and has trouble shooting the commercial.

With Mr. Crandall's back in traction, who was in charge of parents' night, and Miss Sherwood is to take over but is frustrated when she discovers his shorthand notes are in some code that she can't figure out. He's in hospital, heavily sedated and unable to clue Miss Sherwood in on the code. There's greater concern as he's been in contact with Spence Tracie as celebrity guest; but, when famous actress and mother of Montgomery, Melinda McNeil shows up at the school of the arts, she works her way in as guest star. She's apparently taking time off her lead role on Broadway to see her son perform. Being and admirer of McNeil's work, Miss Grant asks her to take over for Mr. Crandall as director. The students at the school are thrilled to be in the presence of a celebrity, all except Montgomery. He explains to Doris that her witty and bright persona is an act to get her to centre stage in the show. Montgomery attempts to change the concept of the show to a 20's motif whilst questioning Leroy's abilities as lead. Shortly after their disagreement, Miss Grant learns that McNeil has invited agents, producers, and representatives as special guests attempting to turn parents' night into her own personal New York audition. Her imperiousness angers Bruno – who she threatens to fire, Leroy – who is learning a routine that he dislikes, and Doris who is passing up her role in the acting segment to Montgomery. After overhearing their discussion about Chess, Miss Sherwood thinks that McNeil and Shorofsky are having a sexual affair. Miss Grant puts Melinda in her place, and she decides to take off once again upsetting Montgomery. It turns out she never had a lead role on Broadway.

With Mr. Crandall's back in traction, who was in charge of parents' night, and Miss Sherwood is to take over but is frustrated when she discovers his shorthand notes are in some code that she can't figure out. He's in hospital, heavily sedated and unable to clue Miss Sherwood in on the code. There's greater concern as he's been in contact with Spence Tracie as celebrity guest; but, when famous actress and mother of Montgomery, Melinda McNeil shows up at the school of the arts, she works her way in as guest star. She's apparently taking time off her lead role on Broadway to see her son perform. Being and admirer of McNeil's work, Miss Grant asks her to take over for Mr. Crandall as director. The students at the school are thrilled to be in the presence of a celebrity, all except Montgomery. He explains to Doris that her witty and bright persona is an act to get her to centre stage in the show. Montgomery attempts to change the concept of the show to a 20's motif whilst questioning Leroy's abilities as lead. Shortly after their disagreement, Miss Grant learns that McNeil has invited agents, producers, and representatives as special guests attempting to turn parents' night into her own personal New York audition. Her imperiousness angers Bruno – who she threatens to fire, Leroy – who is learning a routine that he dislikes, and Doris who is passing up her role in the acting segment to Montgomery. After overhearing their discussion about Chess, Miss Sherwood thinks that McNeil and Shorofsky are having a sexual affair. Miss Grant puts Melinda in her place, and she decides to take off once again upsetting Montgomery. It turns out she never had a lead role on Broadway.

Failing to keep straight faces during an acting exercise in Mr. Crandall's class where the students are to portray an "emotional" truth while telling him "I Love You," Doris and Montgomery agree to tell the truth for an entire day upon Doris' suggestion while stirring things up: Doris suggests that Michelle has big hips making her insecure, she reveals to Miss Sherwood that Miss Grant doubts her ability to pull off an African tribal dance for Mr. Shorofsky's faculty show. Betting that she can do what Miss Sherwood can, Miss Grant and her trade places and teach each other's classes. Failing as a dance teacher, Miss Sherwood seeks Leroy's help. Montgomery reveals that he, Bruno, Julie and the other classmates didn't practice their assignment, which upsets Mr. Shorofsky who upsets Mrs. Berg when raises his voice at her. With what Mr. Shorofsky calls "the crazies" taking over, everyone puts their petty differences aside when Mr. Shorofsky is attacked by an intruder in the school. The show is reworked so as not to dishonour him, but he protests the revision and escapes to be with his friends for the show.

Julie's mom is apprehensive about job hunting and Julie has a morning rehearsal for her part as a centerpiece mannequin in a new act but she misses rehearsal to stay with her hyperventilating mother. The kids decide to replace Julie with a mannequin which, of course, she isn't too thrilled about. Miss Sherwood has Jeff Harris, a graduate student, as student teacher in her class. Miss Grant coaches Julie's mom in finding a job while Julie and Mr. Harris start getting romantically involved. With both Miss Grant and Miss Sherwood realizing this development, Miss Sherwood warns Mr. Harris about the dangers with getting personally involved. Jeff tells her that he only plans to do an article on Julie, depicting her move from Grand Rapids to New York. Jeff and Julie develop a serious relationship mostly based on Mr. Harris' revelations of nervousness as an aspiring journalist but his article takes a turn in direction when his boss tells him to get some dirt on the school. Julie's mom learns after being excited about getting a job that they were planning to hire her as a numbers' runner and Julie discovers that Jeff is scheming to scandalize both Julie and the school. Both revelations get the two thinking about moving back to Grand Rapids.

Miss Sherwood overhears Leroy probing Danny to let him copy his assignment while at a breakfast café and after already giving him an extension, she demands that he hand it in by the start of class that morning. After not receiving the assignment and catching Leroy dancing it up in the hallways, Miss Sherwood asks Leroy to have his parents come in to speak with her - a request to which he's not thrilled. Leroy manages to prolong the meeting with the help of a forged letter, courtesy of Danny. Frustrated with being evaded, Miss Sherwood opts to go to Leroy's house where she learns that he lives in a meager apartment alone with no parents to look after him. Her anger turns to empathy and she lets Leroy off on the assignment but Miss Grant, who has had a tough past as well, makes her challenge him again for his own sake. Convinced that the new wave smash single "Gimme That," popular among Montgomery and the rest of his peers, is cacophony, Bruno composes a mindless song parodying Mr. Shorofsky to prove his point. Montgomery secretly records the song and submits it to The Physic Powers, a local new wave band who express an interest in Bruno. Montgomery openly reveals his intentions to profit from Bruno's pending work with the group. With a flimsy record contract in the works, the gang expresses its concern with Montgomery's exploitation of Bruno just when Mr. Shorofcky makes Bruno realize that he shouldn't compromise his integrity for money.

After finishing her morning jog, Miss Sherwood discovers a dog in the school with the janitor Tim. When she asks him of the dog's whereabouts, he denies seeing a dog. We learn shortly that he is indeed aware of the animal. Doris' allergies act up in the presence of dogs or people who have been around them confirming Miss Sherwood's discovery of a dog in the school. Miss Sherwood confronts Tim who gets upset by the accusation of being a liar. Curious, Doris gets Bruno and Danny to try to find where the dog is being kept. They discover old Broadway dancer Birdie Whelan has been living in the janitor's quarters after falling short of his rent. He's the owner of the dog and old dance rival Tim has been hiding him there. The kids decide to keep their secret to spare Tim's job and Birdie's living space but of course in the school of the arts, that doesn't happen. They plan a benefit to raise money for the two. The kids arrange a benefit for Tim and Birdie but Miss Sherwood informs them that they would be expelled for courting favour for an employee. Determined to do the benefit, Doris revamps the benefit as a fundraiser for Clumpy, the dog. On a lighter note, Birdie is aware of Leroy's dancing talents and encourages him to listen to Miss Grant. Meanwhile, Mr. Shorofsky has order a table tennis table in which he plans to move into Miss Grant's classroom. Mr. Shorofsky creams Julie and Mr. Crandall and breeches his agreement to store the table against the wall. Miss Grant sets up a match between Mr. Shorofsky and Lang Peyton-Smythe, a neighbour of hers, and she beats him.

Mr. Shorofsky's old girlfriend, and survivor of the Holocaust decides to pay him a visit. Leroy wants his mother to be present for parents' day, but neither of them can afford to have her flown in from Detroit. The gang decides to surprise Leroy.

When Bruno learns that a famous composer stole his original music, he decides to find and confront him. Budget cutbacks call for the termination of one of the school's teachers: either Sherwood or Crandall. Crandall gets cut, but the teachers meet with city board representatives to offer putting off their raises in order to keep Crandall. The kids gather around Crandall at his goodbye party and sing "Starmaker." Crandall's job is saved for one year in exchange for the school not getting approved new lighting in the auditorium. To celebrate, the kids sing and dance to "Hot Lunch" (played in the original film). Coco does not appear in this episode.
